And that for a card that was as easy to come by as walking into your neighborhood super target and buying the preconstructed package with 2 complete ready to play decks for a little more than the individual price of this single card which happens to be less than 2 yrs old right now!! Makes no sense. Insane. What it tells me is, sell your Mox's and Lotus's, your Time reversals and Time Walks, your Thoughtseize's n Clique's and so on and so forth NOW, while the getting is good. Everyone else that wants one, just wait. Sooner or later they will be reprinted (even if they're banned) and when that happens the new ones will be worth double the old ones. An investment, as most people know, is like gambling. Only they flipped it on us! Now they took the gamble part out and as long as you A). Know your history. And B). Know that history will repeat itself, then you're all set! Just be patient, watch for the deck list spoilers and then play middle man by buying them all up, waiting 600 days and double your investment! Shoot, Magic the Gathering pays better dividends then BANKS. And there's NO risk! I love it : P

193867: Demonic Tutor.author: DarthParallax
193867: Demonic Tutor.text_parsed:
Best Duel Decks series card, ever, period. no arguments. Counting Mythics.

This is how Dan Greene cantrips.

EDIT: Now with the Release of Innistrad Block, I've decided to do a Two-Part Case File/Vorthos' Dissertation on Liliana Vess/Liliana of the Veil. Follow the link to see Part One.

Duel Decks: Divine/Demonic; Liliana/Garruk- Kothoped (Demonic Tutor) decides to send Liliana after a powerful ancient evil magical artifact of doomyness. Garruk and Liliana meet, she curses him casually and forgets all about him, Garruk develops an unnatural obsession over her. Damn women. Liliana, upon acquiring the Chain Veil, and being a Black Mage, sees a new way to win: Kill the Boss(es). Innistrad: Kothoped destroyed, hunting Griselbrand. Not only probably kills Griselbrand with aid from Sorin and Avacyn, I could even see Avacyn and Sorin encouraging Liliana to take Gissa the ghoulcaller with her when she leaves. Dark Ascension: Helvault spoiled, Griselbrand almost as much as a shoe-in for Avacyn Restored as Asha was for Alara Reborn.....wait.
Well, either way, I'm the first to try autocarding Griselbrand. :)

Avacyn Restored: I really can't imagine both Garruk, the Veil-Cursed and Liliana of the Veil 'Walking away from Innistrad alive. Garruk's 'story' is that he had a childhood, did some stuff, is a green Planeswalking Beast Hunter, and now is Cursed by 'the Witch', and Liliana's story is that she's 100-years old, makes pacts with Demons and Nicol Bolas frivolously, and now has a powerful ancient evil magical artifact of doomyness, with no moral scruples. She might also be seducing Jace, the Mind Sculptor as a side hobby. One of these characters has no current purpose in life without the other, while Liliana had an entire intriguing unresolved world-spanning plot with all of the Who's-Who in the Multiverse before she'd even met Garruk. Sorry Beast Boy, of all the forests in all the planes in all the Multiverse, she just happened to be 'Walking through yours. :p

193867: Demonic Tutor.author: RevLycan
193867: Demonic Tutor.text_parsed: I am starting back up into magic and see that Demonic Tutor is restricted. What is the restricted number that I can have in a deck? I am assuming it is just 1?
193867: Demonic Tutor.text_posted: I am starting back up into magic and see that Demonic Tutor is restricted. What is the restricted number that I can have in a deck? I am assuming it is just 1?

193867: Demonic Tutor.author: Ferlord
193867: Demonic Tutor.text_parsed:
Heeheehee RevLycan. Yes, you can just play 1 if it's "restricted".

I appreciate your desire to get back into Magic, but what you're suggesting is to get into Vintage. In Vintage, you can essentially play 1 copy of any of the cards banned in Legacy. As in, you could play 1 copy of Black Lotus ($3000+/ea), 1 copy of Ancestral Recall ($600+), 1 copy of Time Walk ($500+), etc. etc. etc. People really don't play Vintage. It's far too expensive to spend nearly $10,000 on a deck that only you and a few others can play. It's like the Fortune 500 of the Magic community.

If you have a Tutor and want to play it, start in EDH (Commander). It's legal there, you only need 1 copy of each spell (since you can't play more than 1 copy of a spell (excluding basic lands)), and many, MANY more people play EDH. It's perhaps the most popular casual format.

But in terms of Tutor, I love how there's new art for (arguably) the best card in Black. As many can tell, cards made pre-2003 (pre-new border) had a different, more 'story book' art style than now. Now, cards are darker, and use more definite shapes and figures. It's good WotC gave this card new art to compliment the old art, similar to Dark Ritual. In fact, it's the same situation.
Now all we need is a duel deck that has Yawgmoth's Will, Mind Twist, Sinkhole, and Vampiric Tutor.

193868: Lord of the Pit.author: Weretarrasque
193868: Lord of the Pit.text_parsed:
Nowadays that we have Jund and Golgari, getting to sacrifice a creature every turn can actually be quite an advantage. Plus, you get a giant flying, trampling 7/7 demon. I know that it's not the best card (Or even close to Akroma's equal), but I think it deserves a better rating than it has right now (the new art alone is worth 3 stars!). And at least when he deals 7 to you, he doesn't tap like some other demons.

Try him with Dragon Appeasement and Golgari Germination for some fun. :)

193868: Lord of the Pit.author: Leshrac_Nightwalker
193868: Lord of the Pit.text_parsed:
I've given him a 4, but it's not for his quality, unfortunately.

Everyone here has already hit the nail on the head - compared to more recent offerings (most notably Xathrid Demon), Lord of the Pit is not overly strong. The people comparing him to his product's angelic counterpart - Akroma, Angel of Wrath - are on the money too; it is not a favourable comparison for the demon.

Still, I made a point of picking up a couple of copies of this printing recently because the flavour-lover in me couldn't resist! This card is a classic - any player from back in the day is familiar with Lord of the Pit. This most recent art is just phenomenal - it really emphasizes how much of a badass this creature is. His new flavour text is just incredibly awesome - that comment is addressed to you! I cannot think of any other cards which actually threaten you with their flavour text.

It's certainly not at a mindblowing power level nowadays, but the creature is so cool and embodies black's philosophy so well that I still look on him fondly.

193868: Lord of the Pit.author: yyukichigai
193868: Lord of the Pit.text_parsed:
The classic combo with this guy was always a timely Spirit Link, so you could essentially tell him to STFU and GBTW every upkeep, not to mention gaining 7 life whenever he attacks or blocks. Now that we have Vampiric Link, you don't even have to get out of mono-black to make that happen, though he has to be the only guy on the board due to the sacrifice being mandatory. Still, not a bad deal.

Also, I'm sure I'm not the only one to have noticed this, but Lord of the Pit synchronizes very well with Breeding Pit. I wonder if that means he's just the lord of any pit full of tasty munchable creatures....

And this printing is quite an upgrade. Thumbs up. The new Oracle wording is clearer (dear god did we ever have the fights over whether Lord of the Pit could eat itself, back then. Check the old wording to see why.) The new art is stellar (going with Chippy was a fantastic choice for Lord's revival, his artwork for Abyssal Persecutor is awesome). The new flavor text is perfect. Heck, even the expansion symbol looks cool on this guy.

Lord of the Pit's one of five Beta creatures to become immediately and enduringly iconic (Lord of the Pit, Serra Angel, Shivan Dragon, Gaea's Liege, and Tim), and kudos to Wizards for reviving 'em one by one.

Lord of the Pit is infamous for causing you to lose the game. In the early days, we didn't have anything like Bitterblossom...

193868: Lord of the Pit.author: Morgaledh
193868: Lord of the Pit.text_parsed:
New artwork is fail, no one who respects this card would play anything but the original art. Still, all sorts of new possibilities for this guy these days. Reassembling Skeleton is my current favorite. I also play this in my rat deck - my wife hates it.

This is the card that made me want to start playing this game. First, I just love saying "Lord of the Pit." Then there's the artwork... nothing like it, man (on the ORIGINAL, that is). As far as the suicide aspect, dying to this thing because I wasn't able to control it was so flavorful that it was almost ok. I mean, I started playing D&D/AD&D back in 81, so I got that if you summoned a demon and screwed around with it, you'd die. No cacodemon spells here. And when I didn't die, but used my summoned fiend to crush my opponent? All was right with the world.

This card isn't about what is better and what is worse. This card is about, well, this card. And it has to be a 5/5, because this is Magic, and it's a Lord of the Pit.

193868: Lord of the Pit.author: SorianSadaskan
193868: Lord of the Pit.text_parsed:
I feel obligated to remind you new generation players for what reasons the Pit Lord deserves the mythic rank as our old timers appreciated him as it is.

Consider that he is a 7/7 makes him quite the heavy hitter, like most Green Heavy Creatures, he is an more than adequate offender AND defender.

The Trample allows him to override chomp block tactics been initiated against him, and not all non-black heavy hitters may have this, if they do, they are mostly in low toughness which leaves them vulnerable to red instants or snipe shots.

The flying brings his threat to a whole new level since your opponents are forced to take drastic measures: as White you have to prepare flyers to hold him off; Blue can do the same or simply return/counter but in the late 7th turn, better pray they've saved enough counter-spells; Red is dog meat if he/she cant win the game before he comes out in the 7th turn; and Green has to get heavier hitters to turn you over into defensive measure before or after.

Let's not forget the Lord of the Pit is BLACK, and Black is associated with destroy, which makes him immune to black destroy factors while on contrast to the non-black creatures can be casually taken out.

In short statement, The Lord of the Pit is a flying, trampling 7/7 threat with Black Destroy Immunity all in ONE card. His upkeep in creature sacrifice/7 self-dmg is a reasonable cost consider how much damage you are potentially doing, though it may turn out suicidal if facing Pacifism or Arrest type Auras, it is something a player of this caliber using the Pitlord should understand knowing full well when to cast it or keep in hand.

Even though Shroud, Hexproof and Protection mechanics have put up a challenge to this creature, as long as he enters the battlefield, he will always be a major threat that can end the game in 3 turns when caught off guard with only Walls, 5/5 beast, or a 2/5 flying Azure Drake at the defenders position.

193871: Akroma, Angel of Wrath.author: Jedijoe

193871: Akroma, Angel of Wrath.author: adrian.malacoda
193871: Akroma, Angel of Wrath.text_parsed:
@Ferlord

Per the Comprehensive Rules, protection is a static ability that permanents have (CR 702.15a). Static abilities are active only while a permanent is on the battlefield (CR 112.3d) and a card ceases to be a permanent if it is not on the battlefield (CR 110.1).

So no. Akroma's protection works only while she's a permanent (i.e. on the battlefield). She is not a permanent if she is in the graveyard, hand, or library; thus, she isn't protected in those zones.

However, Necromancy and Animate Dead bring a creature back onto the battlefield and attach themselves to that creature. When Akroma is brought onto the battlefield, she has protection from black. Akroma's ability will cause these enchantments to be unable to attach themselves to her, and she will be sacrificed. Zombify, Buried Alive, Reanimate or Surgical Extraction will work on her, because they don't target or attach to her while she is on the battlefield.

@WarioMan

The duel decks themselves go for over $100 too. :(

193871: Akroma, Angel of Wrath.author: DarthParallax
193871: Akroma, Angel of Wrath.text_parsed:
Ok, so this seems to be the only card immune to people hating on the reprint art.

But, even if somebody wanted to complain, I finally have an explanation. Check out Linvala, Keeper of Silence, Angelic Arbiter, and Balance. This is a much more 'White' Akroma than the original Legions one. In some ways, Akroma, Angel of Fury was simply putting the old Akroma in the correct card frame.

Akroma is pretty damn badass either way.

EDIT: it has been a long and prestigious career for Akroma, but I suspect that Avacyn, Archangel of Innistrad (also known as Sorin Markov's Galatean girlfriend), may finally top Akroma as the most powerful Angel in Magic. Judging by Vault of the Archangel we are already looking at Flying, First Strike, Vigilance, Lifelink, Deathtouch, Protection from Vampires, Werewolves, and Zombies. That really seems actually reasonable, unless they make her a Demon-hoser instead/as well? I wonder what the mana cost and power/toughness will be though?
Protection from non-human creatures? it's still too early to be absolutely sure what form her protections will take, or if she gets First Strike and Vigilance or not, but she really will be a Flying, Lifelink, Deathtouching Black White Legendary Angel. I'd put money on that.

Edit Again: Wrong on just about everything, lol. But speculation is so fun! (even if I'm hopeless at it) Stil, Avacyn, Angel of Hope might be more powerful than Akroma if you give her a WORLDSLAYER.

j-mind: let me make this as obvious as possible: Of course I was thinking of using Kaalia of the Vast- and where Kaalia isn't legal, why wouldn't I play Quicksilver Amulet or some other way of being faster than CMC? Why not Birthing Pod in standard?

If you look at every creature and think 'this sux because I can't get it out til turn X' then you aren't thinking very well. By that token, Emrakul the Aeons Torn and Progenitus would be the two worst creaures in Magic, because if you only ever tried using Basic Lands to summon them, Emrakul is a turn 15 and Progenitus is a Turn 10-13 depending on if you draw too many of some basics and not enough others.

After I first saw the card Tinker, and ESPECIALLY after I saw Kaalia of the Vast, I started to realize that CMC is the least important stat of a card, except if you are running Erratic Explosion or stuff like that.

193871: Akroma, Angel of Wrath.author: nunzioni
193871: Akroma, Angel of Wrath.text_parsed: This is a very overrated card. I am not against eight mana cards in general, if you cheat them out or ramp up to them, they can be very effective threats. However, If you are going to do all that for one card, it should come much closer to ensuring you victory. A good finisher, what this card should be, gives you a massive threat that has to be dealt with, at the same time as making sure your opponent's threats are stopped (See Gisela, Stormtide Leviathan, and Elesh Norn). This acts as a powerful beater, but its abilities only affect itself, and don't stop your opponent at all. If you haven't lost any life, it takes four hits from Akroma to kill you, and if you had a victory plan set up before this is played, you will probably still win. Gisela, on the other hand, is in my opinion the best angel in magic, because it is the kind of card that lets you win even if you seemed to have no chance otherwise. Don't get me wrong, this is still a good card, and i expect it to be played in some competitive formats, but it shouldn't be rated so high, (higher than Black Lotus in fact!,) regardless of the art, which is amazing and way better than the original.

193871: Akroma, Angel of Wrath.author: pedrodyl
193871: Akroma, Angel of Wrath.text_parsed:
Epic art, Chippy couldn't have done any better on this one.

When you look at finishers like this (for control or ramp or whatever you're playing) you look for a few things. 1) Effectiveness and 2) Resiliency. Akroma's 6/6 flying first strike trample haste vigilance takes care of the effectiveness, and protection from black and red gives her a considerable amount of resiliency, considering a lot of creature removal comes in black and red.

193871: Akroma, Angel of Wrath.author: RecurringMemories
193871: Akroma, Angel of Wrath.text_parsed:
4/5

The card is epic!
Amazing abilities on a tank body and the art is beautiful to boot. Why not 5/5? One simple reason; my utter hatred of foil cards. I think it was the dumbest things WotC ever did. I don't mind random foils as much as I toss them aside (or trade if they have value) but printing certain cards in ONLY foil? Even worse is the "Premium" constructed decks. It means I have to pay MORE to get a non-foil Entomb. Damn you WIZARDS!!! Ok I feel better now. Besides all that she's great...I'd still buy the older versions though.

193871: Akroma, Angel of Wrath.author: Tivoko
193871: Akroma, Angel of Wrath.text_parsed:
This version, imho, looks rather blah. Maybe it's because the old art has become to iconic to me but I feel like the face and hair in this version is just off. The wet clingy hair looks better on a zombie than an angel and her face shows no emotion which I find odd for a being known as the Angel of Wrath.

Some like the eerie soulless look of this version and I can respect that, I just don't agree. I am glad that both versions exist, though this is one card I'm happy to own an original version of.

As for the card itself, I love it. It's not often that I have her hit the table and not end the game shortly thereafter; she's my favorite angel and the measuring stick I compare most finishers to.

193871: Akroma, Angel of Wrath.author: Ferlord
193871: Akroma, Angel of Wrath.text_parsed:
This was the first good card I owned.

When I was beginning Magic, I went to a local card store and asked what I should start with. I wanted to play with my friend since he had a good deck from Mirrodin.

The store clerk said that this Duel Deck came in just yesterday and is going for about $20 dollars. I was a little skeptical, but then they rationalized that it has two different decks, and will sell like hot cakes. Not knowing any better, I purchased it, thinking, "Well, if this is going to become valuable...".

4 years later, I've spent more money on Magic than anything else; got into EDH; and have a great group of friends who play Magic as well.

I guess you could say she changed my life.

193872: Luminous Angel.author: KnightLord77
193872: Luminous Angel.text_parsed: The new artwork is absolutely gorgeous, but the mana cost is too expensive. I'm okay with the WWW in its mana cost, because it's an angel card that gives you white flying Spirit creature tokens. Three White makes perfect sense to me. But it should cost 2  less colorless mana. After all, you won't even start getting the tokens until the beginning of your next turn. Until then, you have just paid 7 CMC for a 4/4 flyer. I can think of a lot more powerful cards (or even two separate cards, for that matter) that could help you out a whole lot more. To make this card worth it, you have to make sure that it lasts at least two or three turns. That late in the game, you have to assume that your opponent is going to have things that will squash a 4/4.

196990: Angel of Mercy.author: Ferlord
196990: Angel of Mercy.text_parsed:
Yeah, Vampire Nighthawk overclassed this.

However, this was first printed in Invasion, while Nighthawk came around in Zendikar. Compare creatures and spell power from then to now. It's like comparing Phyrexian Negator to Phyrexian Obliterator. You can't really, because a 3-cost 5/5 with trample was huge, no matter the drawback.

However, do note that the life gain is forced. If for some reason the life gain is bad (like Transcendence), you can't stop it.

That being said, you shouldn't play this with Transcendence anyway. That's like playing Planar Void in a Reanimation deck.

196998: Reya Dawnbringer.author: BegleOne
196998: Reya Dawnbringer.text_parsed:
Obviously this card isn't designed to be hard-casted...

I tend to run a copy in every reanimation deck I build, just because it fits the theme so well. Only problem is that it's almost always better to directly reanimate the creature that'll lock my opponents down or kill them that turn instead of reanimated the Reya and waiting for her ability to resolve the next turn. Blazing Archon, Iona, Shield of Emeria and even Voidstone Gargoyle are all creatures I tend to pull out before this girly, even if she can pull them out a turn later herself. That turn is a doozy.

I think the old art with the uplit radiant "O"-face and spread legs was a little bit hotter as well. Love the short hair. She seems more tranquilly afterglowing in this picture. Angels in miniskirts is such a nice thought.

196998: Reya Dawnbringer.author: SwordOfKaldra
196998: Reya Dawnbringer.text_parsed:
@RedCarmine

No, the kicker only takes effect when you pay the cost. You only have the opportunity to pay the cost when you cast the spell. If you have a way to cast it without paying its mana cost then you can pay the additional kicker cost and the kicker will take effect. If you just put a creature into play you're not casting it so you can't even pay the kicker cost.
196998: Reya Dawnbringer.text_posted:
@RedCarmine

No, the kicker only takes effect when you pay the cost. You only have the opportunity to pay the cost when you cast the spell. If you have a way to cast it without paying its mana cost then you can pay the additional kicker cost and the kicker will take effect. If you just put a creature into play you're not casting it so you can't even pay the kicker cost.

196999: Serra Angel.author: Salient
196999: Serra Angel.text_parsed:
I feel sort of sorry for Greg Staples for having painted the Serra Angel art that's famous for not being the gorgeous portrait by Douglas Schuler (on the Beta/Revised/Unlimited/4th edition angels). I guess it's still better than being the artist whose Serra Angel everyone has forgotten (Mark Zug for 7th edition, apparently).

Probably Staple's artwork here is just fine, but the old Serra Angel art triggers nostalgia like no other card in the game (except maybe Lord of the Pit, for that wistful "remember when we thought this was good" feeling).

Serra Angels with the old artwork and the new flavor text would be grand, maybe in a future From the Vault set.

197000: Serra's Embrace.author: kiseki
197000: Serra's Embrace.text_parsed:
This shouldn't be played in any manner of constructed magic without some way to save the creature from removal.
It is about right for an uncommon aura. This could have been pushed further, but not much (at this rarity). I have won many games with this, usually on Slippery Bogle or Sacred Wolf. When you are loading up a hexproof critter with auras, the vigilance really matters. If you put this on just about anything turn four or better, your turn three drop will outclass your opponent's side of the board, and then you can follow it up with a surprise Epic Proportions when they finally get something that can block.
The other option is Something like Darksteel Sentinel, but the other embraces are better on him since he already has vigilance.

197003: Cackling Imp.author: iyearP
197003: Cackling Imp.text_parsed:
A 2/2 flyer for 4 is nothing special, but the tap to have a player lose 1 life is AMAZING.
1: Where the 2/2 flyer may not be able to attack due to whatever defenses a player may have, the activated ability cares not about such defences.

2: Since this is an activated ability, it can be done at any time.

3: Most importantly, life loss, unlike damage, CANNOT BE PREVENTED. Not by spells, not by abilities. That makes this VERY strong versus a protection or cleric deck, because they can't stop the life loss.

So it is expensive and somewhat weak, but life loss is an awesome mechanic.
2.5 stars

197006: Serra Advocate.author: Stinga
197006: Serra Advocate.text_parsed: @ Kelptic183  Well, if this is better than 1000 drills, frankly I think that is a pretty good thing for drills. +2/+2 is, on average, the size of a bear. So lets say you do three drills a day, in a little under three years you will have done 1001 drills. Which is presumably about as good as this. You are now some crazy combo of a bear and a soldier. So prolly around the size of an elephant. Which is pretty bloody impressive. Also, keep in mind, that your average soldier does more than three drills a day and trains for longer than three years. So, frankly, I would rather have a six-year-trained soldier than an angel on my side. So, remember kids, with proper training you too can punch out dragons!

197014: Angelsong.text_posted: I prefer [autocard]Holy Day[/autocard], since a deck that needs the ability to prevent this combat damage will need the main effect more than it needs the cycle. However, they're both solid cards, and the right sort of deck might even get away with 4 of each.

197014: Angelsong.author: NoobOfLore
197014: Angelsong.text_parsed:
It's a white Fog. Yeah, it costs one more than Holy Day, but the versatility of being to cycle it when you're in a good position can be the difference between a dead card, and dropping that spot removal you needed, or the land drop you had to get for the bomb waiting in your hand.
This is a good card. It's not game-breakingly good. It's not the sort of good that gets banned, that gets called OP in tournament play. It's the sort of good that pervades many of Magic's beloved classics. It's Serra Angel good. It's Shock good.

It's just a good, fair card.
I rate it 5/5 not because it's "better" than Baneslayer Angel, but because these are the sorts of cards I like to see printed. They're the cards I like to play with and against.

197016: Oni Possession.author: ValenceTheElectron
197016: Oni Possession.text_parsed:
This is one of the most brutal cards ever, in terms of art. Just intensely violent, and fits the card perfectly.

Oh, and Juparave, you must obey the card, otherwise it would have said "At the beginning of your upkeep, you MAY sacrifice a creature." So yes, you would have to sacrifice the enchanted creature if you had no creatures left.

The way to work this card, though, is with creatures with unearth abilities, like Viscera Dragger's. You unearth it, then enchant it with Oni Possession to give the resurrected creature extra strength.

Either that, or use it with a creature who has an ability activated when it is put into the graveyard. A Puppeteer Clique can strike for extra damage, then once sacrificed return to the battlefield and resurrect a creature from your opponents battlefield under your control!

The way to work this card, though, is with creatures with unearth abilities, like [autocard]Viscera Dragger[/autocard]'s. You unearth it, then enchant it with Oni Possession to give the resurrected creature extra strength.

Either that, or use it with a creature who has an ability activated when it is put into the graveyard. A [autocard]Puppeteer Clique[/autocard] can strike for extra damage, then once sacrificed return to the battlefield and resurrect a creature from your opponents battlefield under your control!

197016: Oni Possession.author: AColonyOfAnts
197016: Oni Possession.text_parsed:
@Baconradar

The main aspect of Oni Possession is the fact it adds a sacrifice mechanism to your deck. Run it with Breeding Pit or any other token generator (Reassembling Skeleton works fine too), alongside Mortician Beetle and Butcher of Malakir. Now every turn, you sack a creature (preferrably a token), put a +1/+1 counter on Mortician Beetle, have your opponent sacrifice another creature though Butcher of Malakir, and you put another +1/+1 counter onto Mortician Beetle. At this stage you've lost nothing, your opponent's lost a creature, and Mortician Beetle just got +2/+2 on your upkeep alone. The fact that Oni Possession gives +3/+3; trample; demon spirit is simply icing on the cake. You don't understand this card at all; sacrifice isn't a weakness.

197016: Oni Possession.author: Baconradar
197016: Oni Possession.text_parsed:
What? Why does this have a 3+ rating? This card is basically terrible. The drawback is huge and it's an aura which invites 2 for 1s anyway.

What do you do when they pacify your creature? You sac him and lose both cards for 1. Same if they kill him, same if they can in any way stall or block him. Bad bad card.

To those saying I don't understand how sacrifice is a good thing - you are wrong. I understand full well how a good sacrifice outlet (low or no cost, instant speed) is a powerful part of an engine. This card isn't even a good sacrifice outlet. It happens only once on your turn, at a time you can't control and is very open to removal.

So if you're playing it as a sacrifice outlet, why aren't you playing any one of the many, many better sacrifice outlets?

If you playing it as a buff, why not play with a buff that doesn't have a big drawback.

A deck that wants exactly both those things is pretty niche and even there the card is only mediocre at both - it's a poor sacrifice outlet and it's only a single +3+3 and trample (plus the cost of the stuff you're sacrificing) for three mana if you're after the buff.

197016: Oni Possession.author: DarthParallax
197016: Oni Possession.text_parsed:
I would like to point out that 'every' Magic card is 'broken' if you know how to use it/have the right deck for it. Visions of Beyond is TECHNICALLY Ancestral Recall (!), and not even that hard to enable (Jace, Memory Adept or any of a myriad of Innistrad cards, and that's just what's NEW. Mind Funeral and Glimpse the Unthinkable do great work as well.)

What is good about this card is that it's not just a sacrifice outlet: it's a flavorful one. It was printed in a Duel Decks, and while precons and DD in particular can have some great cards (destroying the myth that precons suck, look at Premium Graveborn's ENTOMB or this very deck's DEMONIC TUTOR), it is still true that these products are tailored to please Vorthos before Spike. For example, that Demonic Tutor could have been a Vampiric Tutor, or a Mystical Tutor, which arguably possibly better for costing less....but there was no way the Demon Deck would have run the Vampire Tutor.

The fact is, there ARE better sacrifice outlets-among artifacts especially-but they picked this card because it fit the Theme. As an aura, this is easier to destroy, because it is only as strong as the combined weaknesses of TWO cards, not one: the enchantment itself, which has no protection, and the creature it is dependent on to survive. This card was picked for this deck because it's kind of a top-down card and it's 'thing' is "It turns your creature into a Demon!"

So that's the cons of it, given fair exposure. While it's easy for all the cards with good art and a possibly useful ability to get a fanclub on Gatherer, I felt that people were brushing aside Baconradar just because he didn't fall for that.

On the other hand, there ARE good uses for this card, and one thing that Baconradar got sorely wrong was "A deck that wants exactly both those things is pretty niche and even there the card is only mediocre at both" Compare Grave Pact to Butcher of Malakir, or Anowan, Ruin Sage to Abyss (?) I think (?) Forgive me if I'm mixing up my enchantments, but there are some new black Vampires that mimic classic old cards and functionally the vampires are just better: You get the effect of the Enchantment, AND you get the flying damage and blocking of the body. In game 1, which kinds removal your opponent has might be relevant, but every 75-card Deck/Sideboard combination should be able to come up with an answer to each major card type, making that factor less important in game 2. The point I'm trying to make is that the card with 2 uses- being both a creature and an enchantment or other effect, is better than the card that just does one of those jobs. Maybe a deck isn't going to be looking for exactly those two effects, but if you think of this as a split card, where one side says 'pump creature' and the other side says 'sac engine', then it begins to look more like one of those good vampires I was talking about before.

That all being said, I find that Sacrifice-effects are somewhat difficult to exploit for some reason, and in order to keep even or better on tempo and card advantage, you almost always have to run a Grave Pact-like effect that punishes your opponent/s whenever something of yours dies. I'm not saying that it's a bad way to go if you have all the cards, just pointing out that it does need more support than the average strategy. My final rating is 2.5-3 stars. In other words, I think this is a balanced card, which we need more of.

197017: Otherworldly Journey.author: artemoila
197017: Otherworldly Journey.text_parsed: when it targets a token do you get it back at the end of the turn?
197017: Otherworldly Journey.text_posted: when it targets a token do you get it back at the end of the turn?

197017: Otherworldly Journey.author: Falgorn
197017: Otherworldly Journey.text_parsed:
You don't. As soon as it finishes resolving, having exiled the token, state-based effects are checked, they see a token not on the battlefield, and it ceases to exist.

Another example is casting Warp World while having tokens on the battlefield. Technically, you have to shuffle them into your library as well and remove them from it after you finish resolving it, when you check the state-based effects.

Note that this doesn't mean that these tokens could re-enter the battlefield.

110.5f A token that’s phased out, or that’s in a zone other than the battlefield, ceases to exist. This is a state-based action; see rule 704. (Note that if a token changes zones, applicable triggered abilities will trigger before the token ceases to exist.)

110.5g A token that has left the battlefield can’t come back onto the battlefield. If such a token would return to the battlefield, it remains in its current zone instead. It ceases to exist the next time state-based actions are checked; see rule 704.

Moreover, you ignore them while revealing cards from the top of your library.
110.5e A token is subject to anything that affects permanents in general or that affects the token’s card type or subtype. A token isn’t a card (even if represented by a card that has a Magic back or that came from a Magic booster pack).
197017: Otherworldly Journey.text_posted:
You don't. As soon as it finishes resolving, having exiled the token, state-based effects are checked, they see a token not on the battlefield, and it ceases to exist.

Another example is casting [autocard]Warp World[/autocard] while having tokens on the battlefield. Technically, you have to shuffle them into your library as well and remove them from it [i]after[/i] you finish resolving it, when you check the state-based effects.

Note that this doesn't mean that these tokens could re-enter the battlefield.

[i]110.5f A token that’s phased out, or that’s in a zone other than the battlefield, ceases to exist. [u]This is a state-based action;[/u] see rule 704. (Note that if a token changes zones, applicable triggered abilities will trigger before the token ceases to exist.)
	
110.5g A token that has left the battlefield can’t come back onto the battlefield. If such a token would return to the battlefield, it remains in its current zone instead. [u]It ceases to exist the next time state-based actions are checked;[/u] see rule 704.[/i]

Moreover, you ignore them while revealing [b][u]cards[/u][/b] from the top of your library.
[i]110.5e A token is subject to anything that affects permanents in general or that affects the token’s card type or subtype. A token isn’t a card (even if represented by a card that has a Magic back or that came from a Magic booster pack).[/i]

197017: Otherworldly Journey.author: kiseki
197017: Otherworldly Journey.text_parsed:
A solid, powerful and versatile card.
Save your creatures from wrath, or terror, get an additional enter the battlefield trigger, get increased power and unmorph your angels and dragons.
I have even needed this to stop an attacking creature, which can make the +1/+1 counter annoying, but you do what you need to do.
Compare to momentary blink, which won't save your creatures from wrath, but will get them back quicker for every other reason.

197023: Dark Banishing.author: kowrip
197023: Dark Banishing.text_parsed: This is a solid card.  I do think it's clearly better than Terror and slightly better than Doom Blade.  First of all, the extra 1 mana is not really a big deal since it's only 3 CMC vs. 2 for Terror / Doom Blade.  Secondly, with the introduction of the colored artifacts, there are a lot more artifact creatures to worry about nowadays.  Doom Blade comes close, but regeneration is common enough where I'd rather pay the extra 1 to be SURE the creature stays dead.  4/5

197023: Dark Banishing.author: DarthParallax
197023: Dark Banishing.text_parsed:
http://wizards.com/Magic/Magazine/Article.aspx?x=mtg/daily/ld/238

A really good article for people to read who want to understand why some Commons are even bothered to be given cardboard at all, even today.

"Common Limited Vanilla Creature at 3 Mana" actually hasn't changed by more than about 1 toughness for most of the period of the game. o.O We still get Riot Devils today, which is really just a Red Regal Unicorn!

The only thing I question about the Article is that I think either I don't know how good Dark Banishing is even post-Doom Blade, or this article is failing to be honest about the impact of Doom Blade on Design and Development...however it's worth noting that Go for the Throat is an uncommon.

197024: Breeding Pit.author: yyukichigai

One of the better cards to come out of Fallen Empires. Actually, thrulls in general were the most solid thing to come out of Fallen Empires.

197027: Reiver Demon.author: ICEFANG13
197027: Reiver Demon.text_parsed:
This was the first deck I played, Demonic before I bought any cards, his power, just amazing. I was like "all your creatures die right? cool and mine live? cool!" And by all I mean all. Akroma, Angel of Wrath will die to this effect, a common way to know if a card is effected or not is the D.E.B.T. system.

Damage, all damage dealt to the protected creature will be negated.
Enchant, a creature cannot be enchanted by an enchantment of the protected color (if it changes color
to the protected color the enchantment is sent to the graveyard.)
Block, a creature with protection cannot be blocked by any creature that has the protected color or types etc.
Target, the creature cannot be targeted by any spell it is protected from (or enchanted, there are a few was to get around the targeting of an enchantment, so that is why it is important.)

Destroy is not damage, damage is "X damage" if it doesn't say damage its not damage. of course its not being blocked or enchanted by the effect, and it does not target, so Akroma is destroyed. (for the people that want to call me an idiot I am absolutely sure about this, 100000000% look it up if you want to sit there and bark at the computer).

197027: Reiver Demon.author: Chosen_of_the_Dark_Sun
197027: Reiver Demon.text_parsed: @raverboy1123 Yeah, sorry, but like Eved said you're actually the one who needs to read the rules. Protection does indeed stop all damage from a source of the listed type...except that Reiver Demon doesn't do damage. That's why it says destroy. Protection does not defend against destroy effects, even though it does prevent black destroy effects from targeting it. But since Reiver Demon's ability is untargeted, Protection from Black or Protection from Demons or whatever does not block it, and Akroma and Baneslayer both will be killed by it.
197027: Reiver Demon.text_posted: @raverboy1123  Yeah, sorry, but like Eved said [i]you're[/i] actually the one who needs to read the rules. 197027: Reiver Demon.author: Arachobia
197027: Reiver Demon.text_parsed:
One of my most epic multi-player chaos games was one with this bad boy.

I drew him and a tendrils in my opening hand, and the proceeded to draw lands or useless stuff for most of the rest of the game. I was beaten down to like 5 health. Then the majority of people seemed to think I was dead anyway as they knew all I had drawn once I got to this ridiculously low amount were Phyrexian Arenas.

I bided until I had about 12 Swamps out and dropped this SOB. Everyone's stuff fried and the one thing that survived got Tendriled to death. Everyone had taken such a beating by that point I just smacked the rest of the players off by 6 a turn.

197027: Reiver Demon.text_parsed:
This really happened once with my friend... My friend played with red Goblin-Devil-deck. I played with black-green-deck. My friend started the game...

(When my friend started, I revealed Chancellor of the Tangle from my hand.)

My friend: "HAHA! Best opening hand ever!" (He plays mountain, then Rite of Flame and Ornithopter, then plays Kuldotha Rebirth to sacrifice Ornithopter.)
"...And that wasn't all!" (He plays Vexing Devil.) "Do you wish to take damage?"

Me: I don't think so.

My friend: Well, ok...

(My turn begins...)

Me: "I play swamp, then Dark Ritual, another Dark Ritual, then THIRD Dark Ritual."
(I have seven (B) and one (G) in my mana-pool.) "Now I use all the mana and I cast Reiver Demon..."

My friend: Hoooooly crap...

197034: Twilight Shepherd.author: Donovan_Fabian
197034: Twilight Shepherd.text_parsed:
Pro - an angel that has 5/5 flying vigilance and persist is awesome. Her ability can be played after a combat phase to return creatures/spells that just went to the graveyard. She basically counts as a 5/5 flying vigilance and a 4/4 flying vigilance if she is killed by anything other than an exiling spell, or a spell that uses negative counters. She can persist indefinitely with any way to remove her negative counters like fate transfer and quillspike.

Con - 6 cmc to return cards to hand is decent but will follow wrath of god and day of judgement at 4 cmc rather than before, and assumes you wont be playing anything else on the turn she hits play. You often wont be able to choose what time she gets killed thus causing her to return to play, sometimes netting you nothing back in your hand. Twilight shepherd doesn't actually replay the cards to the field she just returns them to your hand, which can either overload it, be discarded, or work like an expensive evacuate. Exiling her prevents her from coming back again to use her ability. Cauldron haze and cauldron of souls effectively do the same thing, but actually put the creatures back into play, for a lower mana cost (though without the creature addition of the angel herself).

In essence shes a powerful creature, though there are a lot of those around the 6 cmc mark, but its hard to rely on her returning cards to your hand ability, and even if you do you wont be replaying them all right away. Arguably needs some sort of combo that both removes counters from her while letting you kill her on demand like a sacrifice effect. Maybe world queller for example, or fleshbag marauder.
197034: Twilight Shepherd.text_posted:

She basically counts as a 5/5 flying vigilance and a 4/4 flying vigilance if she is killed by anything other than an exiling spell, or a spell that uses negative counters.  She can persist indefinitely with any way to remove her negative counters like fate transfer and quillspike.

Exiling her prevents her from coming back again to use her ability.  Cauldron haze and cauldron of souls effectively do the same thing, but actually put the creatures back into play, for a lower mana cost (though without the creature addition of the angel herself).

197034: Twilight Shepherd.author: PrimeSonic
197034: Twilight Shepherd.text_parsed:
As great as this one may seem, don't forget that the cards go back to your hand, not the battlefield. You still somehow have to recast as many as you can, and most likely you'll find yourself discarding cards that you couldn't drop due to mana shortage.

As great as it is, I'd only play this one in a Persist heavy deck so whatever does go back to my hand can actually make its way back onto the battlefield.

Edit: After actually playing a deck with lots of board wide nuking, I have to say: this is the most combo-licious angel ever printed. If you've got the mana, run 4 and have fun with all the shenanigans you can pull off.

As great as it is, I'd only play this one in a Persist heavy deck so whatever does go back to my hand can actually make its way back onto the battlefield.

[b]Edit:[/b] After actually playing a deck with lots of board wide nuking, I have to say: this is the most combo-licious angel ever printed. If you've got the mana, run 4 and have fun with all the shenanigans you can pull off.

197034: Twilight Shepherd.author: dovakhin
197034: Twilight Shepherd.text_parsed: This can be one of the most useful cards in the game if you use it right. First, build up your creatures to where you have a formidable force to oppose your opponent's creatures. Then, attack with all your creatures for one crushing wave (don't worry about losing them.) Then, summon Twilight Shepherd, who will revive any creatures that died during the wave. As an added bonus, I would recommend adding Heartmender your deck. This guy can make any creature with persist nearly immortal, as he removes any -1/-1 counters at the beginning of your turn, and if your enemy kills heartmender, good news! Heartmender has persist as well! So if you combine twilight shepherd with heartmender, you will have an unstoppable, ever regenerating wave of creatures, as well as any spells, artifacts, instants, or enchantments played on your turn.

197034: Twilight Shepherd.author: blurrymadness
197034: Twilight Shepherd.text_parsed:
For those not getting it, the idea is that she's already on the board. THEN you Wrath of God.

I.E. T7 (or w/e) you attack, some stuff dies and you do damage. You Wrath the board. Your stuff goes back to your hand, she comes back to the field. You have both field advantage and *likely* massive card advantage.

If you have instant-speed reanimator tricks you could keep her in hand for an opponent to wrath the board, then use Shallow Grave on her (by discarding her to the top of the pile via some outlet) and get your stuff back. That is.. however.. far more conditional.

197034: Twilight Shepherd.author: MindAblaze
197034: Twilight Shepherd.text_parsed:
@ unerasablesin and antivitamin

I think the question is about what how the stack works, and the reading of persist. Persist triggers when a creature with persist "dies" (is put into the graveyard from the battlefield.) So say somebody casts Wrath of God and you have two Twilight Shepherds on the battlefield.

Step one; everyone hits the yard.
Step two; each shepherds instance of persist goes on the stack
step three (provided there are no interventions); first instance of persist resolves, causing one shepherd to return to the battlefield.
step four; the angel's ETB effect goes on the stack above the remaining persist ability,
step five; the etb ability resolves returning all creature cards put into your graveyard this turn to your hand,
step six; persist ability resolves, but since the remaining twilight shepherd is in your hand not the graveyard the ability fizzles.
197034: Twilight Shepherd.text_posted:
@ unerasablesin and antivitamin

I think the question is about what how the stack works, and the reading of persist.  Persist triggers when a creature with persist "dies" (is put into the graveyard from the battlefield.)  So say somebody casts Wrath of God and you have two Twilight Shepherds on the battlefield.

Step one; everyone hits the yard.
Step two; each shepherds instance of persist goes on the stack
step three (provided there are no interventions); first instance of persist resolves, causing one shepherd to return to the battlefield.
step four; the angel's ETB effect goes on the stack above the remaining persist ability, 
step five; the etb ability resolves returning all creature cards put into your graveyard this turn to your hand,

197036: Souldrinker.author: mrchuckmorris
197036: Souldrinker.text_parsed:
Someone tell me if I'm wrong, but if you had an Elderscale Wurm out, could you just keep draining your life down to 1, then letting its "return to 7 life" triggered ability resolve, then draining down to 1 again and repeating the process, adding 3 +1/+1 counters to Souldrinker over and over until you went infinite?

The only reason I could think of this not working would be because the Wurm's rules texts says "damage that reduces your life total to less than 7." Since you're paying life for Souldrinker's ability, I wonder if that makes a difference.
197036: Souldrinker.text_posted:
Someone tell me if I'm wrong, but if you had an [autocard]Elderscale Wurm[/autocard] out, could you just keep draining your life down to 1, then letting its "return to 7 life" triggered ability resolve, then draining down to 1 again and repeating the process, adding 3 +1/+1 counters to Souldrinker over and over until you went infinite?

The only reason I could think of this not working would be because the Wurm's rules texts says "[i]damage[/i] that reduces your life total to less than 7."  Since you're [i]paying[/i] life for Souldrinker's ability, I wonder if that makes a difference.

197036: Souldrinker.author: TheWrathofShane
197036: Souldrinker.text_parsed:
Its really to far under the curve for this ability to be any good. Outside of combo this thing is pretty trashy. Example of something you could use today, Moltensteel Dragon. You can pay same mana cost and only 4 life to get a 4/4 flying. This guy demands 6 life to get to 4/4 status and he is stuck on the ground.

3/3 for 4 with this ability would be acceptable. Then you can think about paying 3 life for a 4/4 for 4, kind of under the curve by today's standards. Anything higher is a big life investment but could pay off.

@mrchucknorris
Someone tell me if I'm wrong, but if you had an Elderscale Wurm out, could you just keep draining your life down to 1, then letting its "return to 7 life" triggered ability resolve, then draining down to 1 again and repeating the process, adding 3 +1/+1 counters to Souldrinker over and over until you went infinite?

The only reason I could think of this not working would be because the Wurm's rules texts says "damage that reduces your life total to less than 7." Since you're paying life for Souldrinker's ability, I wonder if that makes a difference.

Yeah life loss is not damage. You would need another card with that combo, perhaps Pestilence? It is not infinite but it is stylish.

197937: Spirit.author: Mode
197937: Spirit.text_parsed:
@rinoh20 It's simple. MasterOfEtherium sacrifices any quality for quantity.
Commenting (if you can even still call it that) this way basically takes no effort at all.
If everyone spammed Gatherer with witless, needlessly capitalized one-liners without commas (unless it's a copy-pasted flavor text or something similar - which is even more pointless), the Card Discussion would be a horrible place.
It's already sad enough that we're talking about him, since this means we give him the attention he craves for.
On top of that, his username keeps defiling my feelings on a perfectly fine card, which bears even more unrightful comments about this troll on the various printings' discussion pages... then again, deep inside our hearts we all know MasterOfEtherium is to Master of Etherium what Chimney Imp is to Yawgmoth's Will.
